channel.title: The weight of the human soul
channel.description:
Yesterday when my cousin was in visit he told me that he read about an experiment years ago by a doctor who happened to have measured the human soul which happens to be 21 grams.
There was a strange experiment by a doctor in Massachusetts back in 1907 that suggests something, indeed, leaves the body at the moment of death. And that something weighs about 21 grams. It seems that Dr. Duncan MacDougall of Haverhill conducted his experiment with the help of six dying patients placed in a specially designed bed. The bed was built on a scale so that they could be weighed before, during and immediately after death. Writing in a journal of American Medicine, Dr. MacDougall told of one patient who was dying of tuberculosis. He wrote: "He lost weight slowly at the rate of one ounce per hour due to evaporation of moisture in respiration and evaporation of sweat. At the end of the three hours and forty minutes, he expired and suddenly coincident with death the beam end (of the scale) dropped with an audible stroke . . . "
Here is an example article of what I'm trying to say: http://perdurabo10.tripod.com/id787.html http://www.snopes.com/religion/soulweight.asp So I'm curious to know what you guys think, what could these 21 grams that leave out of our body in the second of death be? Also if mods believe this is not debate worthy, you can just move to General Discussion I guess.

item.title: The weight of the human soul
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Tutorial, post:62, topic:453087”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=555939.msg4168126#msg4168126 date=1353941530]

massless objects don’t have weight

There is no known object in this universe that doesn’t have mass.

i never said anything about the earth containing massless objects.

Photons.
[/quote]
That is nothing more than a mere theory. Prove to me that they don’t have mass.[/quote]You know what else is a theory? Saying that mass applies to everything. We have not proven either way yet.

Read full topic
item.source: The weight of the human soul

photons are massless when quiescent

item.title: The weight of the human soul
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Niall:

sure I guess, cut off all brain activity (resulting in brain death) and keep the body alive, or vise versa

If this was an answer to me, you are doing it much more risky than necessary (And inconclusive). If the soul make you heavier by applying an extra force, you would fall faster than a dead object in vacuum.

If the soul has mass, we should be able to catch it.

Read full topic

item.title: The weight of the human soul
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:52, topic:453087”][quote author=Bowser jr link=topic=555939.msg4165711#msg4165711 date=1353692752]

It’s probably already been said,

but if a soul did exist, why would it have mass? I thought souls were supposed to be non-physical, leaving your physical body.

Weight != Mass.
[/quote]

I thought about that when I posted it, than said love it let someone correct me.

but ok, a soul shouldn’t have weight, right? It contradicts what soul-believers believe.[/quote]
If the soul act an force on the body, it can make an illusion about weight. A soul must interact with the brain somehow, so it can’t be completely independent from the physical world.

EDIT: I realized that this can be disproved quite easily. 10 points to the first person who can think of an experiment that disprove this idea.

Read full topic
